quiz.title: AP Physics 2
quiz.subtitle: Unit 2, Quiz 5: Thermodynamic Cycles & Kinetic Theory Applications
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Constant volume processes, rms speed, PV diagrams, thermodynamic cycles, work calculations, heat exchange, thermal conduction, isothermal vs adiabatic processes, internal energy changes, entropy

questions.question: In a 15 L rigid, sealed container, there is 1 mole of an ideal gas. The container is initially at 25°C. If the gas is heated to 50°C, what is the new pressure in the container?
questions.explanation: Since the container is rigid and sealed, volume (V) and moles (n) are constant. Using the Ideal Gas Law $PV = nRT$, we solve for P: $P = nRT/V$. First, convert temperatures to Kelvin: $T = 50 + 273.15 = 323.15 K$. Then, $P = (1 \text{ mol} \times 0.08206 \text{ L}\cdot\text{atm/mol}\cdot\text{K} \times 323.15 \text{ K}) / 15 \text{ L} \approx 1.768 \text{ atm}$.

questions.question: A mole of ideal gas at STP is heated in an insulated constant volume container until the average velocity of its molecules doubled. Its pressure would therefore increase by what factor?
questions.explanation: Insulated constant volume ⇒ ΔV = 0. From kinetic theory: $v_{rms} \propto \sqrt{T}$. Doubling $v_{rms}$ ⇒ T increases by factor 4. At constant V and n, P ∝ T ⇒ P increases by factor 4.

questions.question: A sample of gas was first compressed from $V_1$ to $V_2$ at a constant pressure of $P_1$. The sample was then cooled so that the pressure went from $P_1$ to $P_2$ while the volume remained constant at $V_2$. Finally the sample was allowed to expand from $V_2$ back to $V_1$ while the pressure increased from $P_2$ back to $P_1$ as shown in the diagram. Which of the following statements are correct? Select two answers.
options: The area A represents the energy that is lost by the gas in this cycle.
The area A + D represents the '+' work done on the gas during the first compression.
The area D represents the '+' work done on the gas during the final expansion.
There was no energy lost or gained by the gas in this cycle.
questions.explanation: For the cycle: (1) Compression at $P_1$: work on gas = area A+D. (2) Cooling at $V_2$: W = 0. (3) Expansion along diagonal: work by gas = area D. Net work = enclosed area A (counterclockwise) = work done on gas. By first law (ΔU=0 for cycle), net heat out = area A = energy lost by gas.

questions.question: One end of a metal rod of length $L$ and cross-sectional area $A$ is held at a constant temperature $T_1$. The other end is held at a constant $T_2$. Which of the statements about the amount of heat transferred through the rod per unit time are true? Select two answers.
options: The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $A$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $1/(T_1 - T_2)$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $L$.
The rate of heat transfer is proportional to $(T_1 - T_2)$.
questions.explanation: Steady-state heat conduction rate: $\frac{Q}{t} = k A \frac{T_1 - T_2}{L}$, where $k$ is thermal conductivity. Thus, $\frac{Q}{t} \propto A$ and $\frac{Q}{t} \propto (T_1 - T_2)$.

questions.question: On all of the pV diagrams shown below the lighter curve represents isothermal process, a process for which the temperature remains constant. Which dark curve best represents an adiabatic process?
questions.explanation: For expansion: Isothermal: $PV = \text{constant}$, Adiabatic: $PV^\gamma = \text{constant}$ with $\gamma > 1$. Since $\gamma > 1$, the adiabatic curve is steeper than the isothermal curve when starting from the same point.

questions.question: Three processes compose a thermodynamic cycle shown in the accompanying $pV$ diagram of an ideal gas. Process 1→2 takes place at constant temperature (300 K). During this process 60 J of heat enters the system. Process 2→3 takes place at constant volume. During this process 40 J of heat leaves the system. Process 3→1 is adiabatic. $T_3$ is 275 K. What is the change in internal energy of the system during process 3→1?
questions.explanation: For complete cycle: ΔU_total = 0. Process 1→2: isothermal ⇒ ΔU₁₂ = 0. Process 2→3: isochoric ⇒ ΔU₂₃ = Q₂₃ = -40 J. Thus, 0 + (-40) + ΔU₃₁ = 0 ⇒ ΔU₃₁ = +40 J.

questions.question: Two different ideal gases, Helium (mass 4 u) and Oxygen (mass 32 u), are contained in the same vessel at thermal equilibrium. What is the ratio of the rms speed of the Helium atoms to the rms speed of the Oxygen molecules ($v_{He} : v_{O_2}$)?
questions.explanation: At thermal equilibrium, both gases share the same temperature. $v_{rms} = \sqrt{3RT/M}$. Therefore, $v \propto 1/\sqrt{M}$. The ratio is $\sqrt{32/4} = \sqrt{8} = 2\sqrt{2}$.

questions.question: During an isothermal expansion of an ideal gas at temperature $T$, the gas does 150 J of work against a piston. Which of the following is true regarding the heat $Q$ exchanged and the change in internal energy $\Delta U$?
questions.explanation: Isothermal means $\Delta T = 0$, so $\Delta U = 0$ for an ideal gas. By the 1st Law ($\Delta U = Q - W$), if $W = +150$ J (work done by gas), then $Q$ must be $+150$ J.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines the Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics in variable form, where X, Y, and Z represent the temperatures of three distinct systems?
options: X = Y, Y = Z → X = Z
questions.explanation: The Zeroth Law establishes the transitive property of thermal equilibrium: if systems X and Z are both in equilibrium with Y, they are in equilibrium with each other.

questions.question: Which of the following processes would result in the greatest increase in the entropy of an ideal gas system?
questions.explanation: Entropy ($\Delta S$) is defined as $\int dQ/T$. In an isothermal expansion, heat must enter the system ($Q > 0$) to maintain temperature while doing work, increasing disorder. In adiabatic processes, $Q = 0$, and in cooling, $Q$ is removed, decreasing entropy.
